name: Bhanu Pratap
tweet: it‚Äôs a great platform for open-source contributions and quests. It allows you to showcase and apply your skills, and it‚Äôs an amazing place to build both skills and connections.

name: Aditya
tweet: On my first day at Quira, Om introduced me to the platform, where you can contribute, create projects, and even earn money. He also helped me solve my first quest. Later, he introduced me to Rohan Sharma (you!), and I really appreciated how you gave honest and helpful feedback on my project. It was also genuinely fun chatting with you both. By the way, I‚Äôd say Quira has been such a great place to learn, build together, and have fun with the dev folks.

name: Rajesh Adhikari

Since then, I‚Äôve taken part in multiple quests and it‚Äôs helped me grow in more ways than one; sharpening my skills and shifting my mindset. I‚Äôm truly grateful to Quira team and the community for creating such an amazing platform where developers and like-minded people can connect, contribute and grow together :)

name: Yash K Saini

Quira has been a refreshing change: no fluff, real community, real rewards. Great people, Grateful to be part of it. Never leaving this platform.

name: David Pratama
tweet: When I first joined Quira in February 2025, my friends recommended trying a quest ‚Äî like a hackathon ‚Äî called Quira. üßµ

thread.tweet: At first, I thought Quira was just like Devpost ‚Äî a platform for hackathon-style projects. The UI/UX impressed me right away: smooth, simple, and easy to use.
For my first quest (Quest 25), I almost didn‚Äôt join. Many participants were highly skilled professionals, and I felt anxious and unsure about what I could build.
After 2‚Äì3 days of debating, I joined anyway ‚Äî with a new mindset: "Success can only be reached if you start from zero." That gave me the motivation to create something useful for others.
When I submitted my project, I had no expectation of winning. The other entries were amazing ‚Äî far beyond what I had imagined.
Then came the announcement at the Opera House for Quest 25. To my shock, my project was in the Top 2, featured in Rodrigo‚Äôs presentation. I was thrilled and couldn‚Äôt believe it.
That moment made me decide to join every future Quest or Solve Challenge as soon as I can. Huge thanks to friends like Rodrigo, you, Om, and others who‚Äôve supported me!

name: Spandan Mukherjee
tweet:
When I first joined @quira_sh , I thought it‚Äôd just be ‚Äúanother community server.‚Äù
I was wrong. It became one of the best decisions I‚Äôve ever made online. üßµ

thread.tweet:
On my first day, I was just a quiet member, exploring channels and trying to figure out how everything worked.
The welcoming vibe made me stay. The curiosity made me explore more.

Then came my first Quest.
Helping someone solve a problem, sharing resources, or even just being part of a discussion ‚Äî I realized Quira isn‚Äôt about clout, it‚Äôs about building each other up.

Somewhere along the way, I became a Dev Advocate.
Not just a title ‚Äî it meant I could guide others, share my experiences, and help newcomers feel the same way I felt on Day 1: welcome.

I‚Äôve grown here ‚Äî not just as a dev, but as a person.
From learning in public, to leading initiatives, to meeting people who inspire me daily‚Ä¶ @quira_sh has been the bridge between potential and progress.

If there‚Äôs one thing I‚Äôve learned:
Communities aren‚Äôt made of rules or channels ‚Äî they‚Äôre made of people who care. @quira_sh is living proof of that. üíú

Thank you, @quira_sh.
Thank you for the friendships, the growth, the laughs, and the challenges.
If you‚Äôre reading this and wondering if you should join ‚Äî trust me, it‚Äôs worth it. ‚ú®

name: Saloni Verma
tweet: My journey in Quira started when I first made a project for Quest 16. It was a pretty simple AI app, I remember. Along the way, many quests came, and while some were difficult for me to take part in, I did get to know about some amazing open-source projects. But that‚Äôs not all, the developer community is very supportive and vibrant here, and to this very day, it is still growing.

thread.tweet: If Quira ceases to exist someday, I would be a little sad, but also extremely grateful to have been part of a community where developers can make money through open source.
